questions.text: A forensic expert received summon from district court to record his evidence in a criminal case but 2 days back, he already received a summon for civil case in district court for same date. What should the doctor do?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C)Attend court for criminal caseAs per Indian legal precedence, criminal cases take priority over civil cases in court proceedings due to the urgency and seriousness involved—particularly when justice may affect an individual's life, liberty, or public safety. The Indian Evidence Act and Code of Criminal Procedure (CrPC) emphasize the importance of timely evidence in criminal matters to prevent delay in justice.Therefore, when a medical or forensic expert receives summons for both civil and criminal cases on the same date, the expert is legally and ethically bound to attend the criminal court first. Later, the expert can inform the civil court and request a rescheduling based on this prioritization.Incorrect Options:A. Inform both courts and waitMerely informing courts and waiting without attending would be considered non-compliance with a legal summons and may result in legal consequences like issuance of a warrant or contempt notice.B. Attend court for which summon came firstThe chronological order of summons is not the determining factor. Nature of the case (criminal vs civil) is what matters, with criminal cases taking precedence.D. Do not attend either courtThis is clearly wrong and may lead to contempt of court charges or disciplinary action, especially for a government or forensic expert.

questions.text: Leading questions can be asked in?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Cross-examinationLeading questions are questions that suggest the answer within the question itself, typically prompting a "yes" or "no" response. For example:“You were at the crime scene, weren’t you?”According to the Indian Evidence Act, Section 143, leading questions are permitted during cross-examination. This is because the goal of cross-examination is to test the credibility and truthfulness of the witness and to extract contradictions or admissions. The opposing counsel is allowed to put pressure through direct and suggestive questioning to uncover inconsistencies.Incorrect Options:B. Re-examinationLeading questions are not allowed in re-examination unless permitted by the court. Re-examination is mainly for clarifying doubts or ambiguities from cross-examination.C. AnytimeIncorrect because leading questions are not universally permitted—they are generally restricted to cross-examination and require court permission in other situations.D. Examination-in-chiefLeading questions are not allowed during the examination-in-chief (i.e., when a lawyer questions their own witness), unless the court allows them in specific circumstances, such as to establish introductory facts.

questions.text: A person got stabbed on his anterior thigh and died. His body was brought for postmortem. What type of injury is this?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C)Puncture woundA puncture wound is caused by a long, narrow, pointed object such as a knife, nail, or needle, which pierces deep into the body tissues through a small external wound. In this case, since the person was stabbed, likely with a pointed weapon like a knife, the resulting injury is deep and narrow—classic characteristics of a puncture wound.These wounds typically have small openings but can reach deep anatomical structures, including blood vessels and internal organs.In forensic practice, stab wounds are classified under puncture wounds when the depth > length and width of the external wound.Incorrect Options:A. Incised woundIncised wounds are caused by sharp-edged objects like razors or glass. They are longer than they are deep and have clean, regular margins. A stab is deeper than it is long, so this doesn't apply.B. Penetrating woundPenetrating wounds usually refer to firearm injuries or wounds that enter a body cavity (e.g., thorax, abdomen) and may have an entry without an exit. Since the thigh is involved and not a body cavity, it doesn't qualify as a classic penetrating wound.D. Blunt force injuryThese result from non-sharp objects like sticks, stones, or fists. They cause abrasions, lacerations, or contusions, not deep, sharp injuries like stab wounds.

questions.text: A deceased individual exhibits rigor mortis all over the body and a cold body temperature, with lividity present. Based on these observations, estimate the time since death.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D)12–24 hoursThe estimation of time since death (TSD) in forensic medicine relies on postmortem changes such as body temperature, rigor mortis, and livor mortis (hypostasis/lividity).Rigor mortis begins 1–2 hours after death, becomes fully established by 12 hours, and then gradually disappears by 24–36 hours.Body temperature drops steadily after death, usually becoming cold within 12–18 hours, depending on environmental conditions.Lividity (postmortem hypostasis) typically begins within 30 minutes to 2 hours and becomes fixed by 6–12 hours.In this case:Rigor mortis is present all over, indicating that it has fully developed ? typically seen at 12 hours postmortem.Body is cold ? usually seen after 12 hours.Lividity present (not specified if fixed) ? would be consistent with 6+ hours after deathIncorrect Options:A. 4–6 hoursAt this stage, rigor mortis is just beginning in small muscle groups (e.g., jaw, eyelids), and the body would still be warm to cool, not fully cold.B. 6–8 hoursRigor may have progressed but not yet generalized to the whole body. Body temperature is not fully cold yet.C. 8–12 hoursRigor mortis would be in progress, but not fully established in all muscle groups. Cooling is also not complete in most cases.

questions.text: Two friends were working together at a construction site. A hammer fell from one and struck the other friend’s head. The CT scan revealed a skull fracture showing an inward depression at the site of impact. What type of fracture is this?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B)Depressed fractureA depressed fracture occurs when a blunt object with a small striking surface (like a hammer) hits the skull with sufficient force, causing inward displacement of bone fragments. These fractures are typically seen in the parietal bone and are common in direct trauma cases, such as falls or assault with a heavy object.The inward depression of bone visible on CT is the hallmark of this injury.Such injuries may compress or damage the brain, often requiring surgical intervention depending on severity.Incorrect Options:A. Linear fractureThis is a straight crack in the skull without displacement of bone. It is the most common skull fracture seen with low-impact trauma but does not cause depression of the bone.C. Gutter fractureCaused by grazing bullet injuries, producing a groove-like depression along the surface of the skull. This type of fracture is not due to blunt trauma like a hammer.D. Ping pong fractureThis is a type of depressed fracture seen in infants, where the soft skull bones buckle inward without breaking (like a ping pong ball). Not applicable in adults.
